and renders the features as editable polygons, lines, and points.
. Many of the properties and data getters of those layers are aliased.
object. The following types of geometry are supported:
is not supported. However, you can pass a
property defines the mode used to handle user interaction events (e.g. pointer events) in order to accomplish edits. This can either be a constructor for an
There are a extensive number of modes that come out-of-the-box with nebula.gl. See
An arbitrary object used to further configure the current mode.
(Boolean, optional) - Enables snapping for modes that support snapping such as translate mode.
(Object[], optional) - An array of GeoJSON Features that can be snapped to. This property only needs to be specified if you want to snap to features in other deck.gl layers. All features in this
property distinguishes which features to treat as selected. This property is required when using the
Features are identified by their index in the collection.
Selection of a feature causes style accessors to render a different style, defined in function such as
will render edit handles. Only one feature may be selected while in mode

Note: make sure to pass in the same array instance on each render if you are not changing selection. Otherwise, nebula.gl may clear state on every render (e.g. may clear a drawing in progress if the viewport changes).
event is the core event provided by this layer and must be handled in order to accept and render edits. The
To accept the edit as is, supply this object into the
prop on the next render cycle (e.g. by calling React's
To reject the edit, do nothing
You may also supply a modified version of this object into the
prop on the next render cycle (e.g. if you have your own snapping logic).
(String): The type of edit requested. One of:
: Fired whenever a feature is near completion, and user continued dragging the cursor mid-editing. It fires on pointer move for
. The tentative feature created is different for each mode.
: A position was added (either at the beginning, middle, or end of a feature's coordinates).
: A position was removed. Note: it may result in multiple positions being removed in order to maintain valid GeoJSON (e.g. removing a point from a triangular hole will remove the hole entirely).
: A new feature was added. Its index is reflected in
: A position finished moving (e.g. user finished dragging).
: A feature finished scaling (increase/decrease) (e.g. user finished dragging).
: A feature finished rotating (e.g. user finished dragging).
: A feature finished translating (e.g. user finished dragging).
: An edge started extruding (e.g. user started dragging).
: An edge finished extruding (e.g. user finished dragging).
(Array<number>): The indexes of the edited/added features.
or an object containing additional context about the edit. This is populated by the active mode, see
Guide style properties and data getters
Edit handles are points that are part of an existing geometry used for manipulation or snapping.
The line color for features that are being edited and are not yet finalized. See
The fill color for features that are being edited and are not yet finalized. See
The line width for features that are being edited and are not yet finalized, in units specified by lineWidthUnits (default meters). See

If a number is provided, it is used as the outline width for all objects.
If a function is provided, it is called on each object to retrieve its outline width.
If not provided, it falls back to strokeWidth.
A global radius multiplier for all edit handle points. See
Only draw outline of points. It falls back to outline if not provided. See
The minimum radius of the edit handle in pixels. This prop can be used to prevent the circle from getting too small when zoomed out. See
The maximum radius of the edit handle in pixels. This prop can be used to prevent the circle from getting too big when zoomed in. See

. Each channel is a number between 0-255 and
If an array is provided, it is used as the filled color for all objects.
If a function is provided, it is called on each object to retrieve its color.
The outline color of the edit handle point. See in DeckGl
The rgba color is in the format of
. Each channel is a number between 0-255 and
If an array is provided, it is used as the outline color for all objects.
If a function is provided, it is called on each object to retrieve its color.
The radius of each edit handle, in units specified by radiusUnits (default
If a number is provided, it is used as the radius for all objects.
If a function is provided, it is called on each object to retrieve its radius.

If a string is supplied, it is interpreted as a URL or a Data URL.
One of the valid pixel sources for WebGL texture
A luma.gl Texture2D instance
A plain object that can be passed to the Texture2D constructor, e.g.

. Note that whenever this object shallowly changes, a new texture will be created.
The image data will be converted to a Texture2D object. See textureParameters prop for advanced customization.
If you go with pre-packed strategy, this prop is required.
If you choose to use auto packing, this prop should be left empty.
Method called to retrieve the icon name of each edit handle, returns string or object.
If you go with pre-packed strategy, then getIcon should return a string representing name of the icon, used to retrieve icon definition from given iconMapping.
If you choose to use auto packing, then getIcon should return an object which contains the following properties.
(String, required): url to fetch the icon
: (String, optional): unique identifier of the icon, fall back to url if not specified
are the same as mentioned in iconMapping
(fallback to url) to dedupe icons. If for the same icon identifier, getIcon returns different
will only apply the first occurrence and ignore the rest of them.
The height of each edit handle icon, in units specified by

If a number is provided, it is used as the size for all objects.
If a function is provided, it is called on each object to retrieve its size.

. Each channel is a number between 0-255 and
If an array is provided, it is used as the color for all objects.
If a function is provided, it is called on each object to retrieve its color.
= false, only the alpha component will be used to control the opacity of the icon.
The rotating angle of each edit handle icon, in degrees.
If a number is provided, it is used as the angle for all objects.
If a function is provided, it is called on each object to retrieve its angle.
If on, the edit handle icon always faces camera. Otherwise the icon faces up (z)

Number of pixels around the mouse cursor used for picking. This value determines, for example, what feature is considered to be clicked and what is close enough to be snapped to.
Number of layers of overlapping features that will be picked. Useful in cases where features overlap.
Additional line width in pixels used for picking. Can be useful when
is over a deck.gl layer and precise picking is problematic, and when usage of
that renders the GeoJSON features passed into the
that renders GeoJSON features that aid in editing.
that renders tooltips used in some editing modes.
can be customized by providing the
The features being edited are rendered in the
sub layer whether they are selected or not. If you want to style selected features differently than unselected features, you can accomplish it like this:
There are two types of "guides" rendered in the
While creating a new feature in any of the
modes, portion of a feature which has not been "committed" yet can hold its own props. For example, in

mode, the tentative feature is the last line segment moving under the mouse. For polygons and ellipses, this would be the whole feature during drawing. A tentative feature can be identified by checking if
hotkey is currently supported to drop the Tentative feature entirely. However, if the feature is already committed, the
will do nothing. For example, when a point is drawn, it is finalized and no in drawing status.
Edit handles are the points rendered on a feature to indicate interactive capabilities (e.g. vertices that can be moved). Edit Handles can be identified by checking if
There are also different types of edit handles differentiated by
: this is an edit handle rendered at an existing position of a feature
: this is an edit handle rendered between existing positions (e.g. to add new positions)
: this is an edit handle being moved that can snap to a
: this is an edit handle that will be snapped to if the pointer moves close enough

docBySlug.excerpt: EditableGeoJsonLayer The Editable GeoJSON layer accepts a GeoJSON FeatureCollection and renders the features as editable polygons, lines
